title: Suffixes — -tion and -ness
description: Students learn how the suffixes -tion (turns a verb into a noun meaning 'the act of') and -ness (turns an adjective into a noun meaning 'the state of') change word meanings and parts of speech.
instructions:
1. Introduce the concept of a suffix: letters added to the END of a word that change its meaning and often its part of speech.
2. Present -tion: turns verbs into nouns. Educate → education. Celebrate → celebration.
3. Present -ness: turns adjectives into nouns. Happy → happiness. Dark → darkness.
4. The child builds words with suffix cards and base word cards.
5. Notice spelling changes: educate drops the 'e' before -tion; happy changes 'y' to 'i' before -ness.
6. Write sentences using new words.

items: Base word cards: educate, celebrate, create, decorate, imagine, invent, pollinate, happy, sad, dark, kind, fair, soft, good, lonely, ill, neat, weak
slides.setup_instructions: Write suffix cards on one color and base word cards on another. Sort base words into two groups: verbs (for -tion) and adjectives (for -ness). Have grammar symbols ready.

slides.text: Prefixes go at the beginning of words. Suffixes go at the END! Today we learn two powerful suffixes that change verbs and adjectives into nouns.

The suffix -tion turns a verb (action word) into a noun (thing word). 'Celebrate' is something you DO (verb). 'Celebration' is a THING (noun) — the act of celebrating. Try: create → creation, educate → education, imagine → imagination.

The suffix -ness turns an adjective (describing word) into a noun. 'Happy' describes how you feel. 'Happiness' is the STATE of being happy — it is a thing you can talk about. Try: dark → darkness, kind → kindness, sad → sadness.

slides.prompt: Build as many -tion and -ness words as you can with the cards. In your vocabulary journal, create a two-column page: -tion words on the left, -ness words on the right. Write the base word, the new word, and the part of speech change (verb→noun or adjective→noun). Write 4 sentences using your new words.

slides.text: Suffixes are magic — they transform words from one part of speech to another! When you see -tion at the end of a word, you know it is a noun meaning 'the act of' something. When you see -ness, it is a noun meaning 'the state of' something.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form correct words with -tion and -ness and explain how the suffix changes the part of speech?

parent_notes: Suffixes are more complex than prefixes because they often change the part of speech AND require spelling changes. Focus on understanding the meaning shift first; spelling patterns come with practice. The grammar symbol connection (verb symbol → noun symbol) makes the part-of-speech change visible. Common spelling changes: drop final 'e' before -tion, change 'y' to 'i' before -ness.

title: Subtracting Like Fractions — Fraction Insets
description: Students learn to subtract fractions with the same denominator using fraction insets. They physically remove fraction pieces and record the subtraction equations.
instructions:
1. Review adding like fractions (quick warm-up).
2. Introduce subtraction: 3/4 - 1/4. Place 3 fourth-pieces in the circle, then remove 1. Count remaining: 2/4.
3. Explain: Same rule as addition — keep the denominator, subtract the numerators.
4. Practice with various denominators.
5. Solve word problems involving fraction subtraction.
6. Mix addition and subtraction problems.

slides.setup_instructions: Set out fraction insets. Prepare 8-10 subtraction problems and 3-4 word problems. Open math journal to a fresh page titled 'Subtracting Fractions.'

slides.text: Quick warm-up: 2/5 + 1/5 = ? (3/5). Great! Now let us learn subtraction. If you can add fractions, you can subtract them — same rule, different operation.
Place 3 fourth-pieces in the circle frame. We have 3/4. Now take away 1 piece. How many are left? 2 pieces out of 4 = 2/4. Write: 3/4 − 1/4 = 2/4. The denominator stays the same!
Try 5/6 − 2/6. Place 5 sixth-pieces. Remove 2. Count remaining: 3 sixths. 5/6 − 2/6 = 3/6. Word problem: 'Mom made a pie cut into 8 slices. The family ate 5/8. How much is left?' 8/8 − 5/8 = 3/8.

slides.prompt: Solve with fraction insets and record: 1) 3/4 − 1/4, 2) 5/6 − 3/6, 3) 7/8 − 4/8, 4) 4/5 − 1/5, 5) 6/10 − 3/10. Word problems: 6) 'I had 3/4 of a pizza. I ate 1/4. How much is left?' 7) 'A jar was 5/6 full. We used 2/6. How full is it now?' Draw each problem!

slides.text: Adding and subtracting fractions follow the same rule: keep the denominator, add or subtract the numerators. You have mastered both! Tomorrow, we introduce something new: mixed numbers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child subtract like fractions using the insets and solve a subtraction word problem?

parent_notes: Fraction subtraction with like denominators follows the same logic as addition, so most children pick it up quickly. The physical act of removing pieces from the inset makes the concept concrete. If the child finds it too easy, challenge them with problems that result in zero (3/3 − 3/3 = 0) or with missing parts (? − 2/5 = 1/5). These extend thinking naturally.

title: Ancient Egypt — Hieroglyphics and the Rosetta Stone
description: Students learn about the Egyptian writing system (hieroglyphics), its decline, and how the Rosetta Stone unlocked its secrets. They practice reading simple hieroglyphic symbols and learn about Jean-Francois Champollion.
instructions:
1. Review hieroglyphics from the cartouche activity.
2. Explain: hieroglyphics were used for over 3,000 years, then forgotten after Egypt became part of the Roman Empire.
3. Tell the story of the Rosetta Stone: found in 1799 by Napoleon's soldiers, same text in three scripts.
4. Tell the story of Champollion: the young genius who cracked the code.
5. The child writes a message in hieroglyphics for someone to decode.
6. Discuss: What if we lost the ability to read English?

items: Image of the Rosetta Stone (printed or in book)
slides.setup_instructions: Display the Rosetta Stone image and hieroglyphic chart. Have drawing paper ready for writing messages. Open the history journal to a new page.

slides.text: Hieroglyphics were one of the oldest writing systems in the world. The word means 'sacred carvings.' Egyptians used them for over 3,000 years — on temple walls, tombs, and papyrus scrolls. But by 400 AD, no one could read them anymore.

In 1799, French soldiers in Egypt found a large stone with the SAME message written in three scripts: hieroglyphics, Demotic (everyday Egyptian), and Greek. Since scholars could read Greek, they had a key to unlock hieroglyphics! This stone is called the Rosetta Stone.

A young Frenchman named Jean-Francois Champollion spent years studying the Rosetta Stone. In 1822, he finally cracked the code! He realized hieroglyphics used both pictures for sounds AND pictures for whole words. He could read Ancient Egyptian again!

slides.prompt: In your history journal, write the Rosetta Stone story: who found it, what was on it, and how Champollion decoded it. Then write a secret message in hieroglyphics (at least 3 words) for someone in your family to decode using the alphabet chart.

slides.text: The Rosetta Stone is now in the British Museum in London. Thanks to it, we can read the words ancient Egyptians wrote thousands of years ago. Writing truly is one of humanity's greatest inventions — just like the Third Great Lesson taught us!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child tell the story of the Rosetta Stone and explain why it was important for understanding hieroglyphics?

parent_notes: The Rosetta Stone story is one of the great detective stories of history. Champollion was just 31 when he cracked the code, which makes him relatable to young learners. This connects beautifully to the Third Great Lesson (Coming of Writing). If the child is interested, explore other undeciphered scripts like Linear A — mysteries still waiting to be solved!

title: Africa — Physical Features and the Great Rift Valley
description: Students explore the physical geography of Africa: the Sahara Desert, Great Rift Valley, Mount Kilimanjaro, Congo Rainforest, and major rivers. They focus on the Great Rift Valley as a tectonic feature.
instructions:
1. Show a physical map of Africa.
2. Identify major features: Sahara, Sahel, Congo Basin, Great Rift Valley, Kilimanjaro, Atlas Mountains.
3. Explain the Great Rift Valley: a crack in the Earth's crust where tectonic plates are pulling apart.
4. Connect to Q1 tectonic plates lesson.
5. Identify major rivers: Nile, Congo, Niger, Zambezi.
6. The child creates a physical features map of Africa.

slides.heading: Africa
slides.subheading: Physical Features and the Great Rift Valley

items: Colored pencils (brown, green, blue, yellow, white)
Clay or playdough (optional for relief map)
slides.setup_instructions: Display a large physical map of Africa. Have the atlas open to the Africa section. Prepare drawing materials and optional clay for a relief map.

slides.text: Africa is the second-largest continent and has incredible variety! The north has the Sahara — the world's largest hot desert. Below it is the Sahel, a semi-dry grassland. Central Africa has the Congo Rainforest — the second-largest in the world.

The Great Rift Valley is a massive crack in the Earth stretching from Lebanon in Asia all the way to Mozambique in southeastern Africa — over 4,000 miles! It was formed by tectonic plates pulling apart. Remember our Q1 lesson on tectonic plates? This is where you can SEE them at work!

Africa has incredible peaks: Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania is the tallest mountain in Africa at 19,341 feet — and it has snow on top even though it is near the equator! The continent also has 4 of the world's great rivers: the Nile, Congo, Niger, and Zambezi (with Victoria Falls).

slides.prompt: Create a physical features map of Africa. Label and color: Sahara Desert (yellow), Congo Rainforest (dark green), Great Rift Valley (red line), Mount Kilimanjaro (brown with white peak), Atlas Mountains, Nile River, Congo River, Niger River, Zambezi River, Lake Victoria, and Lake Tanganyika.

slides.text: Africa has every type of landscape: deserts, rainforests, mountains, valleys, rivers, and savannas. The Great Rift Valley shows us that the Earth is still changing — tectonic plates never stop moving! Next lesson, we will explore Africa's countries and people.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate at least 5 major physical features of Africa on a map and explain what causes the Great Rift Valley?

parent_notes: Africa is often poorly taught in Western curricula. This lesson focuses on physical geography, which is objective and awe-inspiring. The Great Rift Valley connection to Q1 tectonic plates reinforces spiral learning. If the child makes a clay relief map, it makes the topography tangible. Mount Kilimanjaro's snow near the equator is a great discussion starter about altitude and temperature.

title: Read Aloud — The Rosetta Stone and Hieroglyphic Decoding
description: Read aloud about the discovery and decoding of the Rosetta Stone, reinforcing today's history lesson through narrative storytelling and discussion.
instructions:
1. Review what we learned in history about hieroglyphics.
2. Read a chapter or passage about the Rosetta Stone discovery.
3. Discuss Champollion as a character: What drove him? How did he feel when he cracked the code?
4. Compare hieroglyphics to our alphabet: similarities and differences.
5. The child writes a journal entry from Champollion's perspective.
6. Add new vocabulary words to the journal.

items: Egypt read-aloud book or separate Rosetta Stone book
slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark the relevant chapter. If your Egypt book does not cover the Rosetta Stone in detail, supplement with another source.

slides.text: We learned about hieroglyphics and the Rosetta Stone in history today. Now let us hear the full story through our read-aloud. Listen for details we did not cover in the lesson.
Read the chapter aloud. Pause to discuss: 'Imagine you found a stone with writing you could not read. How would you feel? What would you try first?'

After reading, discuss Champollion: 'He started learning languages as a child and knew over a dozen by the time he decoded hieroglyphics at age 31. What does his story tell us about the power of curiosity and persistence?'

slides.prompt: Write a journal entry as if you are Champollion on the day you finally cracked the hieroglyphic code. How do you feel? What was the hardest part? What will you do now? Write at least one paragraph in your reading journal.

slides.text: Champollion's discovery opened a window into 3,000 years of Egyptian history. Without the Rosetta Stone, we would not know the names of the pharaohs or the stories on the temple walls. One stone changed everything!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a perspective journal entry that demonstrates understanding of the Rosetta Stone's significance?

parent_notes: The perspective writing activity builds empathy and historical thinking. Accept the child's interpretation of Champollion's emotions — there is no wrong answer. If the child is reluctant to write a full paragraph, let them write a diary entry with shorter sentences or draw a comic strip of the moment of discovery. The key is emotional engagement with the historical event.

title: Suffixes — -ful and -less
description: Students learn the suffixes -ful (full of) and -less (without). They discover that these suffixes create opposites and build words that describe qualities.
instructions:
1. Review -tion and -ness from yesterday.
2. Introduce -ful: means 'full of.' Care → careful (full of care). Hope → hopeful.
3. Introduce -less: means 'without.' Care → careless (without care). Hope → hopeless.
4. Discover the pattern: -ful and -less often create opposites! Careful/careless, hopeful/hopeless.
5. Build word pairs and use them in contrasting sentences.
6. Add to the vocabulary journal suffix section.

items: Base word cards: care, hope, help, thought, thank, rest, power, fear, harm, taste, use, pain, cheer, grace, color, end
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare suffix and base word cards. Sort base words into those that work with -ful only, -less only, and both (creating opposite pairs). Open vocabulary journal to the suffix section.

slides.text: Yesterday we learned -tion and -ness. Today we meet two suffixes that are opposites of each other! The suffix -ful means 'full of.' Cheerful means full of cheer. Colorful means full of color.
The suffix -less means 'without.' Careless means without care. Colorless means without color. Notice something amazing: careful and careless are OPPOSITES created from the same base word!

Try building opposite pairs: hopeful/hopeless, helpful/helpless, thankful/thankless, powerful/powerless, fearful/fearless. Not every word makes both — 'beautiful' exists but not 'beautiless!' Languages have surprises.

slides.prompt: Build all the opposite pairs you can: words with both -ful and -less. Write them in your vocabulary journal in two columns. Then write 4 pairs of contrasting sentences: 'The grateful child said thank you. The thankless child said nothing.' Make each pair show the difference!

slides.text: You now know 6 word-building tools: 4 prefixes (un-, re-, pre-, dis-) and 2 suffix pairs (-tion/-ness and -ful/-less). With just these, you can understand hundreds of words! Keep building your word power.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form correct -ful and -less words, identify opposite pairs, and use them in contrasting sentences?

parent_notes: The opposite-pair discovery (-ful/-less) is a moment of linguistic insight that delights children. Let them discover the pattern rather than telling them directly. Some words only work with one suffix: 'restless' exists but 'restful' is used less commonly. This is a natural feature of English, not an error. The contrasting sentences activity develops sophisticated writing skills.

title: Mixed Numbers Introduction — What is 1 and 1/2?
description: Students are introduced to mixed numbers: numbers that have a whole number part and a fraction part (e.g., 1 1/2, 2 3/4). They build mixed numbers with fraction insets and connect to real-life examples.
instructions:
1. Pose a question: What if we add 3/4 + 2/4? We get 5/4. But 5/4 is more than one whole!
2. Show with insets: 4/4 fills the whole circle with 1/4 left over. That is 1 and 1/4.
3. Define: A mixed number has a whole number part and a fraction part.
4. Practice converting: 5/3 = 1 and 2/3, 7/4 = 1 and 3/4.
5. Connect to real life: recipes (1 1/2 cups), measuring (2 3/4 inches).
6. Build and name mixed numbers with the insets.
materials_needed: Fraction insets (2 complete sets if possible)

slides.heading: Mixed Numbers
slides.subheading: When Fractions Are More Than One Whole

items: Fraction insets — 2 full circle frames if available (or use paper circles)
slides.setup_instructions: Set out 2 fraction inset frames to show 'more than one whole.' If only one frame is available, use paper fraction circles for the second whole. Have measuring cups nearby for real-world connection.

slides.text: Let us add: 3/4 + 2/4 = 5/4. But wait — we only have 4 fourths in a whole circle! Place 4 fourth-pieces to fill one circle completely. That is 4/4 = 1 whole. One piece is left over: 1/4. So 5/4 = 1 and 1/4!
A MIXED NUMBER has a whole number part and a fraction part. 1 and 1/4 is a mixed number: 1 whole and 1 quarter. 5/4 is called an IMPROPER FRACTION: the top number is bigger than the bottom.

Try 7/3: fill one circle with 3 thirds (= 1 whole), fill another with 3 thirds (= 2 wholes), and 1 third is left. 7/3 = 2 and 1/3. Real life: 'The recipe needs 2 and 1/2 cups of flour. That is 2 full cups plus half a cup.'

slides.prompt: Convert these improper fractions to mixed numbers using the insets: 5/4, 7/3, 5/2, 8/5, 9/4, 7/6. Draw each one showing the full circles and leftover pieces. Then find mixed numbers at home: look at recipes, rulers, or measuring cups. Record 3 real-life mixed numbers!

slides.text: Mixed numbers are everywhere! When you say 'I am 7 and a half years old' or 'I need 1 and a quarter cups,' you are using mixed numbers. You can now convert between improper fractions and mixed numbers!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child convert at least 4 improper fractions to mixed numbers and explain what a mixed number represents?

parent_notes: Mixed numbers are a big conceptual leap. The key insight is that improper fractions and mixed numbers represent the same amount — they are two ways of writing the same thing. Physical manipulation with the insets makes this clear. Do not rush to abstract conversion formulas; let the child build understanding through the materials. Real-world connections (recipes, measurements) make mixed numbers relevant.

title: Parts of a Flower — Detailed Nomenclature
description: Students learn the detailed parts of a flower using the Montessori botany nomenclature cards: petal, sepal, stamen (anther and filament), pistil (stigma, style, ovary). They dissect a real flower to identify each part.
instructions:
1. Show a large diagram of a flower with all parts labeled.
2. Present each part using the three-period lesson: name, recognize, recall.
3. Dissect a real flower: carefully separate petals, sepals, stamen, and pistil.
4. Tape or glue dissected parts to paper and label them.
5. Explain each part's function in reproduction.
6. Complete nomenclature card matching work.
materials_needed: Fresh flowers (lilies, tulips, or other large flowers)

items: 2-3 fresh, large flowers (lilies or tulips work best)
White paper for mounting dissected parts
slides.setup_instructions: Set out flowers, magnifying glass, and nomenclature cards. Prepare white paper with lines for mounting parts. Cover workspace with newspaper for easy cleanup.

slides.text: A flower is a plant's reproductive organ — it is how plants make seeds! Every part of the flower has a special job. Today we will take a flower apart and name every piece.

The outer green parts are SEPALS — they protected the flower when it was a bud. The colorful parts are PETALS — they attract pollinators like bees. Together, sepals and petals are the 'outside' of the flower.

Inside: the STAMEN is the male part, with a long FILAMENT topped by an ANTHER (the pollen-maker). The PISTIL is the female part in the center, with the STIGMA (sticky top), STYLE (tube), and OVARY (where seeds form) at the bottom.

slides.prompt: Carefully dissect your flower. Separate and identify: sepals, petals, stamens (count them!), and the pistil. Tape each part to white paper and label it. Use the magnifying glass to look at pollen on the anther! In your science journal, draw a labeled diagram of a complete flower.

slides.text: Every flower you see is a tiny factory for making seeds. The colors and smells that make flowers beautiful to us exist to attract pollinators. Tomorrow we will learn about pollination — how pollen gets from one flower to another!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and name at least 5 parts of a flower (petal, sepal, stamen, pistil, ovary) and explain one function?

parent_notes: Flower dissection is a highlight of Montessori botany. Lilies and tulips are ideal because their parts are large and easy to separate. Avoid composite flowers (daisies, sunflowers) for this first lesson as they are actually clusters of tiny flowers. If fresh flowers are unavailable, use high-resolution printed photos. The nomenclature work follows the Montessori three-period lesson format for learning vocabulary.

title: Botanical Illustration — Drawing Flowers in Detail
description: Students create detailed botanical illustrations of the flowers they dissected in science, focusing on accurate observation, proportion, and labeling in the scientific illustration tradition.
instructions:
1. Show examples of botanical illustrations (historical and modern).
2. Discuss the difference between artistic and scientific drawing: accuracy, proportion, detail.
3. Place a fresh flower specimen next to the child's workspace.
4. The child draws the flower from observation, not imagination.
5. Add fine details: veins in petals, texture of stem, individual stamens.
6. Label all parts with lines and neat print.

items: Fresh flower specimen (same type as dissected in science)
Colored pencils (good quality, many greens and colors matching the flower)
Examples of botanical illustrations (printed or in books)
slides.setup_instructions: Set the flower in a small vase at the child's eye level. Display botanical illustration examples. Lay out drawing materials. Good lighting is important for seeing details.

slides.text: For hundreds of years, scientists drew detailed pictures of plants before cameras existed. These botanical illustrations had to be so accurate that another scientist could identify the plant from the drawing alone!

The key to botanical drawing is OBSERVATION. Look carefully at your flower. Notice the shape of each petal, how the stem connects, how the stamens are arranged. Draw what you SEE, not what you think a flower looks like.

Start with a light pencil outline of the overall shape. Then add details: the curve of each petal, the veins, the texture. Finally, color carefully, matching the exact colors you see. Label all the parts you learned in science.

slides.prompt: Create a botanical illustration of your flower specimen. Draw from observation (look at the real flower, not from memory). Include accurate shapes, proportions, and colors. Use the magnifying glass for tiny details. Label at least 5 parts. Sign and date your illustration.

slides.text: Botanical illustration combines art and science beautifully. Your drawing is both a work of art and a scientific record. Some of the most famous botanical artists, like Maria Sibylla Merian, changed our understanding of nature through their illustrations.
slides.mastery_check: Does the illustration show accurate observation of the real flower with at least 5 labeled parts and appropriate colors?

parent_notes: Botanical illustration teaches careful observation — one of the most important scientific skills. Do not worry about artistic perfection; focus on the child's effort to observe accurately. Compare the drawing to the real flower together: 'What details did you capture well? What was hardest to draw?' Maria Sibylla Merian (1647-1717) is a fascinating figure — a woman scientist-artist centuries ahead of her time.

title: Flower Arranging — Care of the Environment
description: Students learn the Montessori practical life skill of flower arranging: selecting, cutting, and arranging flowers in a vase. This develops fine motor skills, aesthetic sense, and care of the environment.
instructions:
1. Show the flower arranging materials and workspace.
2. Demonstrate: choose flowers, trim stems at an angle, remove lower leaves.
3. Show how to arrange: tallest in the center, shorter around the edges.
4. Discuss color and balance.
5. The child creates their own arrangement.
6. Place the arrangement in a prominent spot and discuss care (water changes).

items: Assorted flowers (from garden, grocery store, or wildflowers)
Tray, towel, and small water pitcher
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the arranging workspace on a tray. Lay out flowers and greenery. Fill a small pitcher with water. Put the vase on the tray. Wear an apron.

slides.text: In Montessori classrooms, children arrange fresh flowers every week. This is part of 'care of the environment' — making our learning space beautiful. Today you will create a flower arrangement.

First, fill the vase halfway with water. Choose your flowers. Trim each stem at an angle with the scissors — this helps the flower drink water. Remove any leaves that would be below the water line (they cause bacteria).

Arrange the flowers: start with the tallest in the center, then add medium flowers around them, and short flowers or greenery around the edges. Step back and look — does it look balanced? Adjust as needed.

slides.prompt: Create your own flower arrangement following the steps. Choose flowers for color, height, and variety. Trim, arrange, and adjust until you are pleased with the result. Clean up your workspace when finished. Place the arrangement where your family can enjoy it.

slides.text: Your arrangement brings beauty to our home! Flower arranging is an art practiced in cultures around the world — from Japanese ikebana to European bouquets. Change the water every other day to keep the flowers fresh.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently trim stems, arrange flowers with attention to height and balance, and clean up the workspace?

parent_notes: Flower arranging is a classic Montessori practical life activity that develops fine motor skills (cutting), aesthetic judgment (color and balance), and responsibility (caring for the arrangement). It also connects to this week's botany lessons. This can become a weekly routine — many children love being responsible for fresh flowers in the home. Grocery store flowers work perfectly.

title: Root Words — The Heart of Word Families
description: Students learn that root words are the base forms from which word families grow. They explore how adding different prefixes and suffixes to the same root creates a family of related words.
instructions:
1. Introduce root words: the core word without any prefix or suffix.
2. Example: 'help' is a root word. Add un- = unhelpful. Add -ful = helpful. Add -less = helpless. Add -er = helper.
3. Build word family trees: start with a root and branch out.
4. Explore roots: play, kind, friend, care, move, work, write.
5. The child creates word family trees in their journal.
6. Discover that some roots come from Latin and Greek.
materials_needed: Prefix and suffix cards from previous lessons

items: Root word cards: help, play, kind, friend, care, move, work, write, act, build
All prefix cards (un-, re-, pre-, dis-) and suffix cards (-tion, -ness, -ful, -less)
slides.setup_instructions: Write root words on brown cards (like tree trunks). Have all prefix and suffix cards from previous lessons. Prepare large paper for drawing word family trees.

slides.text: A root word is the simplest form of a word — no prefix, no suffix, just the core meaning. Think of it as the trunk of a tree. When we add prefixes and suffixes, the tree grows branches!
Let us grow a tree from the root 'play': replay (play again), playful (full of play), player (one who plays), playground (place to play), playful, misplay. One root creates a whole family!
Try 'kind': unkind (not kind), kindness (state of being kind), kindly (in a kind way), kinder, kindest. The root 'kind' carries the meaning through every word in the family.

slides.prompt: Create word family trees for 4 root words: draw a tree trunk with the root word, then branches for every word you can make using prefixes, suffixes, or both! Roots: friend, care, move, write. Challenge: can any word have BOTH a prefix AND a suffix (like un-help-ful)?

slides.text: When you know a root word, you can figure out the meaning of its entire word family! This is one of the most powerful reading strategies. If you see an unfamiliar word, look for a root you know inside it.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify root words and build word families with at least 4 related words per root?

parent_notes: Root word awareness is a bridge to advanced vocabulary. When children understand that 'transport,' 'portable,' and 'export' all contain the Latin root 'port' (to carry), they can decode unfamiliar words independently. At this level, we focus on English root words. Latin and Greek roots will be explored more deeply in upper elementary. The challenge of combining prefix + root + suffix shows word-building mastery.

title: Mixed Numbers — Building and Comparing
description: Students practice building mixed numbers with fraction insets, comparing them, and ordering them from least to greatest. They connect mixed numbers to real-world measurement contexts.
instructions:
1. Review: what is a mixed number? Build 2 and 1/3 with the insets.
2. Compare mixed numbers: Is 1 and 3/4 greater than 2 and 1/4?
3. Strategy: compare whole numbers first, then compare fraction parts.
4. Order a set of mixed numbers from least to greatest.
5. Measure objects to the nearest fraction of an inch (mixed number results).
6. Record all work in the math journal.

items: Fraction insets (2 complete sets for building)
Ruler marked with 1/4 and 1/2 inch increments
5-6 objects to measure (book, pencil, crayon, etc.)
slides.setup_instructions: Set out 2 fraction inset frames. Prepare comparison problems. Gather objects for measuring. Have the ruler ready.

slides.text: Build 2 and 1/3 with the insets: fill one circle with 3 thirds (1 whole), fill another with 3 thirds (2 wholes), and place 1 third in a third frame. Two wholes and one-third = 2 and 1/3.
Compare: Which is greater, 1 and 3/4 or 2 and 1/4? Look at the whole numbers first: 1 vs. 2. Since 2 > 1, then 2 and 1/4 is greater, even though 3/4 > 1/4. The whole number matters more!
What if the whole numbers are the same? Compare 3 and 1/4 with 3 and 3/4. Same whole number (3), so look at the fractions: 3/4 > 1/4. So 3 and 3/4 is greater.

slides.prompt: Compare these pairs (use >, <, or =): 1) 2 1/2 vs 1 3/4, 2) 3 1/3 vs 3 2/3, 3) 4 1/4 vs 3 3/4, 4) 2 2/5 vs 2 3/5. Then order from least to greatest: 1 3/4, 2 1/4, 1 1/2, 2 3/4, 1 1/4. Finally, measure 5 objects to the nearest 1/4 inch — your answers will be mixed numbers!

slides.text: Mixed numbers make measurement precise. When you say a pencil is 5 and 3/4 inches long, that is much more accurate than just saying '6 inches.' Fractions are the language of precision!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compare and order mixed numbers and measure objects to the nearest quarter inch?

parent_notes: Comparing mixed numbers develops number sense with fractions. The 'whole number first' strategy is important but the tricky cases (when whole numbers are the same) require deeper fraction understanding. Measurement is an ideal context for mixed numbers because every real measurement is likely a mixed number. Let the child measure freely around the house for extra practice.

title: Ancient Egypt — Daily Life, Schools, and Social Structure
description: Students explore Egyptian social structure (pharaoh, priests, nobles, scribes, craftspeople, farmers, slaves) and daily life including schools, where only boys from wealthy families learned to read and write.
instructions:
1. Draw the Egyptian social pyramid on the board.
2. Discuss each level: who they were and what they did.
3. Focus on scribes: specially trained writers who kept records.
4. Discuss education: scribal schools were strict, writing was on clay tablets.
5. The child creates a social pyramid diagram with illustrations.
6. Compare Egyptian social structure to modern society.

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a large triangle on the board or chart paper to introduce the social pyramid concept. Have reference materials ready.

slides.text: Egyptian society was shaped like a pyramid. At the very top: the Pharaoh — ruler of all. Below: priests and nobles. Then: scribes and officials. Below: craftspeople and merchants. At the base: farmers and laborers. At the very bottom: slaves.

Most Egyptians were farmers who grew crops in the rich Nile mud. Only about 1 in 100 people could read and write! Scribes were very important — they kept records, wrote letters, and recorded history. To become a scribe, a boy went to school for about 12 years.

Scribal school was tough! Students woke before dawn, practiced writing hieratic (a faster form of hieroglyphics) on pieces of pottery, and were sometimes beaten for mistakes. But a scribe had a good life — no heavy labor, good pay, and the pharaoh's respect.

slides.prompt: Draw a large social pyramid in your history journal. Illustrate each level with a figure and label their role. Write 2 sentences about each level describing what they did. At the bottom, write: 'If I lived in Ancient Egypt, I would want to be a _____ because _____.'

slides.text: Egyptian society was very structured — your position was usually determined at birth. How is this similar to or different from our society today? What seems fair? What seems unfair? These are questions worth thinking about.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 4 levels of the Egyptian social pyramid and explain the role of scribes?

parent_notes: The social pyramid is a simplified model — real Egyptian society had more nuance. The key insight for children is that most people in ancient civilizations were farmers, not pharaohs. The discussion about fairness and social mobility connects history to the child's sense of justice. Handle the topic of slavery age-appropriately: acknowledge it as a historical reality without minimizing its injustice.

title: African Cultures — Music and Storytelling Traditions
description: Students explore African cultural traditions of music (drumming, call-and-response singing) and storytelling (Anansi tales, griots as oral historians). They experience call-and-response music and hear a traditional tale.
instructions:
1. Introduce Africa's rich cultural traditions: over 2,000 languages and countless musical styles.
2. Listen to African drumming and discuss: What instruments do you hear?
3. Practice call-and-response: leader sings/says a phrase, group echoes.
4. Read an Anansi tale (West African trickster spider stories).
5. Discuss griots: West African oral historians who memorized and told the history of their people.
6. The child retells the Anansi tale in their own words.
materials_needed: Audio of African music (phone or computer)

items: Anansi tale book (e.g., 'A Story, A Story' by Gail Haley or 'Anansi the Spider' by Gerald McDermott)
Drum, djembe, or any percussion instrument
slides.setup_instructions: Queue up 2-3 minutes of African drumming music. Have the Anansi book ready. Set out percussion instruments. Display the Africa map.

slides.text: Africa has over 2,000 languages and incredibly rich cultural traditions! Music and storytelling are central to African cultures. Drumming communicates messages, celebrates events, and connects communities.

Let us try call-and-response! This is a musical tradition where a leader sings or says a phrase, and everyone echoes it back. Clap a rhythm — the child copies it. Sing a phrase — the child echoes it. This is how songs have been shared for thousands of years.

Griots are West African storytellers who memorize the history of their people — births, deaths, battles, heroes — and pass it down orally from generation to generation. Before writing, griots were the living libraries! Now let us hear an Anansi tale — stories about a clever spider told by griots across West Africa.

slides.prompt: After hearing the Anansi tale, retell it in your own words in your journal. Then draw Anansi. Write: What lesson does this story teach? Compare griots to our books and libraries — how are they similar and different? Practice a call-and-response rhythm pattern.

slides.text: African storytelling and music traditions have spread around the world. Call-and-response is in jazz, blues, rock, and hip-hop! Anansi tales traveled to the Americas and Caribbean with enslaved people, keeping African culture alive.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the Anansi tale, explain what a griot does, and participate in call-and-response?

parent_notes: This lesson introduces African cultures with respect and depth. Anansi tales are an excellent entry point — they are engaging, funny, and carry moral lessons. The griot tradition connects to the Montessori emphasis on oral history and the Third Great Lesson. If possible, watch a video of a real griot performing. The connection between African and American music (jazz, blues) shows cultural continuity across the diaspora.

title: Read Aloud — An Anansi Tale from West Africa
description: Read a complete Anansi tale aloud, focusing on the trickster archetype, story structure, and the cultural values embedded in the tale. Compare to trickster tales from other cultures.
instructions:
1. Set the scene: Anansi tales come from the Ashanti people of Ghana.
2. Read the story with dramatic voices and expressions.
3. Discuss the trickster archetype: a clever character who uses wits to overcome challenges.
4. Analyze the story structure: problem, clever plan, consequences, lesson.
5. Compare Anansi to other tricksters: Coyote (Native American), Loki (Norse), Br'er Rabbit (American).
6. The child writes or draws their own trickster tale.

items: Anansi storybook (or a second Anansi tale if the first was read in culture class)
slides.setup_instructions: Select a different Anansi tale from the culture class if possible, or re-read with deeper analysis. Create a cozy reading spot. Have the map accessible.

slides.text: Find Ghana on the map of Africa. The Ashanti people of Ghana created the Anansi stories. Anansi is a spider who uses cleverness to trick larger, stronger animals. He is not always good — sometimes his tricks backfire!
Read the tale with dramatic expression. Use different voices for different characters. Pause at the clever moments: 'What do you think Anansi will do? Is this a good plan? What might go wrong?'

After reading, discuss: 'Anansi is a trickster — a character type found all over the world. Coyote plays tricks in Native American stories. Loki causes trouble in Norse myths. Why do you think every culture has trickster stories?'

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, write about the Anansi tale: What was Anansi's problem? How did he try to solve it? Did his trick work? What lesson does the story teach? Then draw a 3-panel comic strip of your favorite part of the story.

slides.text: Trickster tales teach us that cleverness can be both helpful and dangerous. They remind us that brains can be more powerful than brawn — but using tricks on others often has consequences!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child analyze the story structure (problem, plan, consequences) and compare Anansi to another trickster character?

parent_notes: Trickster tales from different cultures make excellent compare-and-contrast material. If the child enjoys Anansi, explore: 'Anansi and the Moss-Covered Rock,' 'Anansi Goes Fishing,' or 'Anansi and the Talking Melon.' The trickster archetype is a sophisticated literary concept accessible through these fun stories. The comic strip activity appeals to visual learners.

title: Suffix Review — Word Building Workshop
description: Students review all four suffixes (-tion, -ness, -ful, -less) through a hands-on word building workshop where they construct words using root cards, prefix cards, and suffix cards simultaneously.
instructions:
1. Review all four suffixes with meanings and examples.
2. Set out all word-building cards: roots, prefixes, and suffixes.
3. Challenge: build the longest word possible (e.g., un-help-ful-ness).
4. Build word equations: root + suffix = new word + meaning.
5. Play a word-building relay game.
6. Create a complete word-parts reference page.

items: All root word cards from this week
All prefix cards: un-, re-, pre-, dis-
slides.setup_instructions: Spread all cards out on a large surface, organized by type (roots in the center, prefixes on the left, suffixes on the right). Have the vocabulary journal open.

slides.text: Today we combine everything: roots, prefixes, AND suffixes! Some words have all three: un- (prefix) + thank (root) + -ful (suffix) = unthankful. dis- (prefix) + agree (root) + -ment (suffix) = disagreement.

Challenge: build the longest real word you can! Can you get prefix + root + suffix + suffix? Like: un- + care + -ful + -ness = uncarefully? Wait — is that a real word? Let us think carefully about which combinations actually work.

Word Building Relay: Set the timer for 3 minutes. How many real words can you build using the cards? Each word earns a point. Words with prefix + root = 1 point. Root + suffix = 1 point. Prefix + root + suffix = 3 points!

slides.prompt: Play the Word Building Relay: build as many real words as possible in 3 minutes. Record each word in your journal with its point value. Then create a 'Word Parts Reference Page': list all 4 prefixes and 4 suffixes with meanings, example words, and an illustration for each.

slides.text: You are now a master word builder! With 4 prefixes, 4 suffixes, and dozens of root words, you can decode and build hundreds of English words. This superpower will help you in every subject and every book you read.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 15 words using various combinations of prefixes, roots, and suffixes?

parent_notes: This workshop consolidates two weeks of word study. The relay game motivates quantity, but check quality too — ensure the words built are real English words. The reference page becomes a permanent study tool. Common errors: adding -tion to words that do not form real words, or misspelling words that require letter changes (happy + ness = happiness, not happyness). Gentle correction builds spelling awareness.

title: Fraction Review — Addition, Subtraction, and Mixed Numbers
description: Students practice all fraction skills learned so far: adding like fractions, subtracting like fractions, converting improper fractions to mixed numbers, and comparing mixed numbers.
instructions:
1. Warm up: 5 fraction addition problems.
2. Practice: 5 fraction subtraction problems.
3. Convert 4 improper fractions to mixed numbers.
4. Compare 4 pairs of mixed numbers.
5. Solve 3 word problems mixing all skills.
6. Play a fraction board game for fluency.

items: Dice and a simple game board (or make one)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a problem set mixing all fraction skills. Keep fraction insets accessible. Create a simple game board where landing on a space requires solving a fraction problem.

slides.text: You have learned 4 fraction skills this quarter. Let us review them all! Skill 1: Adding like fractions (keep the denominator, add numerators). Skill 2: Subtracting (same rule, subtract). Skill 3: Converting improper fractions to mixed numbers. Skill 4: Comparing mixed numbers.
Let us warm up with one of each: Add: 3/8 + 4/8 = 7/8. Subtract: 5/6 − 2/6 = 3/6. Convert: 11/4 = ? (11 ÷ 4 = 2 remainder 3, so 2 and 3/4). Compare: 2 1/3 and 2 2/3 (2 2/3 is greater).

Word problem combining skills: 'I had 7/4 of a pizza (that is 1 and 3/4 pizzas). I ate 2/4. How much is left? First convert 7/4 to a mixed number... or subtract first: 7/4 − 2/4 = 5/4 = 1 and 1/4 pizzas left!'

slides.prompt: Complete the mixed practice set: 5 addition, 5 subtraction, 4 conversions, 4 comparisons, and 2 word problems. Show all work with pictures. Then play the Fraction Game: roll dice, solve the problem on the space you land on, advance if correct!

slides.text: You have built a solid fraction foundation: adding, subtracting, mixed numbers, and comparing. These skills will serve you in every math topic going forward. Fractions are not scary — they are just numbers!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly complete at least 16 of 20 fraction problems across all four skill types?

parent_notes: This review session is critical for consolidation. Note which skill types cause difficulty — that is where more practice is needed. The game format keeps review engaging. If the child excels, introduce improper fractions in addition: '3/4 + 3/4 = 6/4 = 1 and 2/4.' If they struggle, go back to one skill at a time with the insets.

title: Pollination — How Flowers Make Seeds
description: Students learn about pollination: how pollen travels from the anther of one flower to the stigma of another. They explore different pollination methods (wind, insects, birds, bats) and the co-evolution of flowers and pollinators.
instructions:
1. Review flower parts from the previous lesson.
2. Explain pollination: pollen must travel from anther to stigma.
3. Show how bees collect pollen: pollen sticks to their fuzzy bodies.
4. Discuss other pollinators: butterflies, hummingbirds, bats, wind.
5. Demonstrate with a model: use cotton swabs to transfer 'pollen' (colored powder) between flower diagrams.
6. Discuss why pollination matters for food production.
materials_needed: Colored powder or chalk dust (as pollen)

items: 2 large flower diagrams with labeled parts
Yellow chalk dust or colored powder (as 'pollen')
Pictures of pollinators (bees, butterflies, hummingbirds, bats)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up 2 flower diagrams on the table. Sprinkle 'pollen' (chalk dust) on the anthers of one. Have cotton swabs ready. Display pollinator pictures.

slides.text: Remember the parts of a flower? The anther makes pollen (tiny grains that contain the male cells). The stigma is the sticky top of the pistil (the female part). For a seed to form, pollen must travel from an anther to a stigma. This journey is called POLLINATION.

How does pollen travel? It cannot walk! Pollinators help: bees visit flowers for nectar, and pollen sticks to their fuzzy bodies. When they visit the next flower, some pollen rubs off onto the stigma. Pollination!

Different flowers attract different pollinators: bright red flowers attract hummingbirds, white flowers that open at night attract bats, strong-smelling flowers attract bees. Wind-pollinated plants (like grasses) do not need colorful flowers — they produce clouds of pollen that blow through the air.

slides.prompt: Simulate pollination: dip a cotton swab into the 'pollen' on Flower 1's anther, then touch it to Flower 2's stigma. In your science journal, draw the pollination process step by step. Create a chart matching 4 types of pollinators with the flower characteristics that attract them.

slides.text: Without pollination, there would be no fruits, no seeds, and no new plants! Bees are especially important — they pollinate about 1 out of every 3 bites of food we eat. That is why protecting pollinators is so important.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the pollination process, name 3 types of pollinators, and describe how flower features attract specific pollinators?

parent_notes: The pollination simulation makes an abstract process concrete. Real pollen under a magnifying glass is fascinating if available (tap a flower's anther onto dark paper). The co-evolution concept (flowers evolved colors/scents to attract specific pollinators) is a powerful example of how organisms adapt to each other. The food connection (1 in 3 bites from bee pollination) makes this personally relevant.

title: Quadrilaterals — Squares, Rectangles, Parallelograms, Trapezoids
description: Students classify quadrilaterals using the Montessori geometry cabinet. They learn that all quadrilaterals have 4 sides but differ in their parallel sides, equal sides, and right angles.
instructions:
1. Define quadrilateral: any shape with 4 sides (quad = 4, lateral = sides).
2. Present from the geometry cabinet: square, rectangle, parallelogram, rhombus, trapezoid.
3. Classify by properties: parallel sides, equal sides, right angles.
4. Show relationships: a square is a special rectangle, which is a special parallelogram.
5. The child sorts and traces quadrilaterals.
6. Create a quadrilateral family tree showing relationships.

items: Geometry cabinet quadrilateral drawer (or cardboard cutouts)
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the quadrilateral shapes from the geometry cabinet. Have geometry sticks ready for construction. Open math journal to a new page titled 'Quadrilaterals.'

slides.text: 'Quad' means 4, 'lateral' means side. A quadrilateral is any shape with exactly 4 sides. But not all quadrilaterals are the same! Let us meet the family members.

SQUARE: 4 equal sides, 4 right angles. RECTANGLE: 2 pairs of equal sides, 4 right angles. PARALLELOGRAM: 2 pairs of parallel sides, opposite sides equal. RHOMBUS: 4 equal sides, opposite angles equal. TRAPEZOID: exactly 1 pair of parallel sides.

Here is the amazing part: a square IS a rectangle (it has 4 right angles). A rectangle IS a parallelogram (it has 2 pairs of parallel sides). So a square is also a parallelogram! It is like saying 'a poodle is a dog is an animal.'

slides.prompt: Trace each quadrilateral from the geometry cabinet into your math journal. Label each with its name and properties (parallel sides, equal sides, right angles). Build each shape with geometry sticks. Create a 'Quadrilateral Family Tree' showing how the shapes are related.

slides.text: Quadrilaterals are everywhere: doors (rectangles), tiles (squares), kites (rhombuses), and traffic signs (trapezoids). Now you can name them all and explain what makes each one special!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and identify 5 quadrilaterals and describe at least 2 properties of each?

parent_notes: The hierarchical classification of quadrilaterals (a square is a rectangle is a parallelogram) is a challenging concept that parallels biological classification. Use the geometry cabinet pieces physically — have the child place the square inside the rectangle frame to show it 'fits.' The family tree diagram makes the relationships visual. Finding real-world examples reinforces the lesson.

title: African Drumming — Rhythm Patterns and Communication
description: Students explore African drumming traditions, learning that drums were used for communication as well as celebration. They learn 3-4 basic rhythm patterns and practice maintaining a steady beat.
instructions:
1. Discuss how drums were used in Africa: celebrations, communication, storytelling.
2. Show pictures and videos of djembe drumming.
3. Teach basic drumming techniques: bass (center of drum), tone (edge), slap (snap).
4. Learn 3 rhythm patterns of increasing complexity.
5. Practice maintaining a pattern while the parent plays a different one (polyrhythm).
6. Create a drum circle with any available percussion.
materials_needed: Drum or hand drum (or bucket/pot with lid)

items: Hand drum, djembe, or improvised drum (overturned bucket)
Device for playing African drumming audio
Rhythm pattern cards (written as: B = bass, T = tone, S = slap, - = rest)
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a drumming space with room to move. Have drums and percussion accessible. Queue up African drumming audio. Write rhythm patterns on cards.

slides.text: In many African cultures, drums were not just for music — they were for COMMUNICATION! The 'talking drum' of West Africa could imitate the tones of spoken language, sending messages between villages. Drums called people to ceremonies, warned of danger, and celebrated victories.

Three basic sounds: BASS — hit the center of the drum with your flat palm (deep, low sound). TONE — hit the edge with your fingers (medium, ringing sound). SLAP — snap your fingers on the edge (sharp, high sound). Practice each separately.

Pattern 1 (simple): BASS-BASS-TONE-TONE. Pattern 2 (medium): BASS-rest-TONE-SLAP-BASS-rest-TONE-SLAP. Pattern 3 (challenge): BASS-TONE-TONE-SLAP-rest-BASS-BASS-TONE. Practice each until you can play it without thinking.

slides.prompt: Practice all 3 rhythm patterns until you can play each one smoothly. Then try: you play Pattern 1 while your parent plays Pattern 2 at the same time (polyrhythm!). Listen to how they fit together. Create your own 8-beat pattern and teach it to your parent.

slides.text: Drumming connects us to one of the oldest forms of human music-making. African rhythms influenced jazz, rock, blues, and hip-hop. Every time you hear a drum beat in modern music, you are hearing echoes of Africa!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child maintain a steady 8-beat rhythm pattern and distinguish between bass, tone, and slap sounds?

parent_notes: Drumming is an excellent activity for developing rhythm, coordination, and concentration. If you do not have a drum, upturned buckets, pots, and boxes all work. The polyrhythm experience (two different patterns at once) is a key element of African music and is more challenging than it sounds. Even a minute of successful polyrhythm is an accomplishment. Let the child move and dance while drumming — African music is whole-body expression.

title: Suffix Application — Finding Suffixes in Reading
description: Students apply suffix knowledge while reading independently, identifying suffixed words and analyzing how the suffix changes the base word's meaning and part of speech.
instructions:
1. Review all 4 suffixes quickly.
2. The child reads independently for 15-20 minutes.
3. Flag words with suffixes using sticky notes.
4. After reading, analyze each flagged word: suffix, base word, part of speech change.
5. Write a reading response paragraph.
6. Compare prefix and suffix word-finding from the past two weeks.

items: Suffix reference card from earlier this week
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the reading spot with sticky notes and the suffix reference card. Have the vocabulary journal ready for after reading.

slides.text: Quick review: -tion means 'the act of' (verb → noun). -ness means 'the state of' (adjective → noun). -ful means 'full of' (noun → adjective). -less means 'without' (noun → adjective). Now find them in your book!
As you read, flag every word with one of our 4 suffixes. Also look for OTHER suffixes we have not studied yet: -ly, -er, -est, -ment, -able. If you find a new one, flag it with a different color!

After reading, go back to your flagged words. In your vocabulary journal, for each word: write the word, underline the suffix, identify the base word, note the part of speech change, and write your own sentence using the word.

slides.prompt: Read for 20 minutes, flagging suffix words. Record at least 5 familiar suffixes and 2 unfamiliar suffixes in your journal. Write a reading response paragraph about the chapter. Challenge: did you find any words with BOTH a prefix and a suffix?

slides.text: In two weeks, you have learned 4 prefixes and 4 suffixes. These 8 word parts help you understand thousands of English words! Keep collecting words — your vocabulary journal is becoming an incredible resource.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently identify suffixed words while reading and correctly analyze the suffix, base word, and meaning?

parent_notes: The transition from studying word parts in isolation to finding them in authentic reading is the critical step. If the child finds fewer suffix words than prefix words, that is normal — suffixes are harder to spot because they often change the spelling of the base word. Finding words with both a prefix AND a suffix (e.g., 'unthankfulness') shows mastery of the word-building concept.

title: Fraction Problem Solving — Real World Applications
description: Students apply all fraction skills to real-world problem solving: cooking (doubling recipes), sharing (equal distribution), measuring (construction projects), and data (survey results expressed as fractions).
instructions:
1. Present real-world contexts where fractions are used.
2. Cooking: A recipe needs 3/4 cup flour. You want to make double. How much flour?
3. Sharing: 3 children share 2 pizzas equally. How much does each get?
4. Measuring: A board is 3 and 1/2 feet long. You cut off 1 and 1/4 feet. How long is it now?
5. The child solves 4 real-world problems and creates 2 of their own.
6. Discuss: Where else do you see fractions in daily life?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 6-8 real-world fraction problems on cards. Have measuring cups and ruler available for hands-on exploration. Open math journal.

slides.text: Fractions are not just for math class — they are everywhere! Let us solve real problems. Cooking: 'A cookie recipe calls for 3/4 cup of sugar. You want to make double the recipe. How much sugar?' 3/4 + 3/4 = 6/4 = 1 and 2/4 = 1 and 1/2 cups!
Sharing: '3 friends equally share 2 pizzas. How much does each person get?' Each pizza cut into 3 equal pieces = 6 pieces total. Each person gets 2 pieces = 2/3 of a pizza!

Measuring: 'A shelf is 2 and 3/4 feet long. You need to cut 1 and 1/4 feet off one end. How long is the remaining piece?' 2 3/4 − 1 1/4: whole numbers: 2 − 1 = 1. Fractions: 3/4 − 1/4 = 2/4. Answer: 1 and 2/4 = 1 and 1/2 feet.

slides.prompt: Solve these problems showing all work: 1) A recipe needs 2/3 cup butter. You triple it. How much? 2) 4 kids share 3 cakes equally. How much each? 3) A ribbon is 4 1/2 feet. You cut off 2 1/4 feet. How much is left? 4) Create 2 of your own real-world fraction problems and solve them!

slides.text: Fractions are the math of everyday life: cooking, building, sharing, measuring, music, sports statistics. The more comfortable you are with fractions, the more capable you are in the real world!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child solve real-world fraction problems and create their own meaningful fraction problems?

parent_notes: Real-world application cements fraction understanding. If possible, actually bake something this weekend using fraction measurements — doubling a recipe is the most natural fraction practice imaginable. The measuring cup and ruler make fractions tangible. Creating their own problems demonstrates the highest level of understanding (Bloom's taxonomy: create). Look for fraction moments all week.

title: Africa — Countries, People, and Diversity
description: Students explore Africa's political geography: the 54 countries, diverse peoples and languages, and major cities. They learn that Africa is not a single culture but a continent of incredible diversity.
instructions:
1. Show a political map of Africa: 54 countries!
2. Locate major countries: Egypt, Nigeria, South Africa, Kenya, Ethiopia, Morocco, Congo.
3. Discuss diversity: over 2,000 languages, many religions, vast cultural variety.
4. Learn about major cities: Cairo, Lagos, Johannesburg, Nairobi.
5. The child labels at least 10 countries on a blank Africa map.
6. Research one African country of their choice for a mini-report.

slides.setup_instructions: Display the labeled political map prominently. Provide a blank map for the child's labeling work. Have the atlas accessible for research.

slides.text: Africa has 54 countries — more than any other continent! It is home to 1.4 billion people who speak over 2,000 languages. Africa is NOT one country or one culture — it is a continent of incredible diversity.

Let us find some key countries: Egypt (northeast, along the Nile — we know this one!). Nigeria (West Africa, most populous country — over 200 million people). South Africa (southern tip). Kenya (East Africa, famous for wildlife). Ethiopia (one of the oldest civilizations in Africa).

Major cities: Cairo, Egypt (20 million people — one of the world's largest cities!). Lagos, Nigeria (15 million — growing fast). Johannesburg, South Africa (a major economic center). Nairobi, Kenya (a tech hub called 'Silicon Savannah').

slides.prompt: Label at least 10 African countries on your blank map (including Egypt, Nigeria, South Africa, Kenya, Ethiopia, Morocco, Algeria, Congo, Tanzania, and Ghana). Color each one differently. Then choose one country to research: write 5 facts about it (capital, population, language, one unique feature, one famous landmark).

slides.text: Africa is a continent of superlatives: the longest river, the largest desert, the most languages, the youngest population. It is also the continent where humanity began! Everything connects to the Second Great Lesson — the Coming of Life and then Humans.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate at least 8 African countries on a map and share 3 facts about one country they researched?

parent_notes: This lesson combats the common misconception of Africa as a monolithic entity. Emphasize diversity: Nigeria alone has over 500 languages! The 'Silicon Savannah' reference shows modern Africa as innovative and dynamic. Let the child choose which country to research — personal interest drives deeper learning. If they are drawn to a less well-known country, that is great exploration.

title: Check Apple Mummification Experiment — Results
description: Students check the results of the apple mummification experiment started in Week 10. They observe, compare, measure, and analyze which preservation method worked best, connecting to Egyptian mummification science.
instructions:
1. Retrieve the 4 apple experiment cups from last week.
2. Observe each apple piece: color, size, texture, smell.
3. Measure and compare: which shrank most? Which is best preserved?
4. Record observations in the science journal.
5. Determine the winner: which method best preserved the apple?
6. Connect results to real Egyptian natron mummification.

items: Camera or phone for documenting results
slides.setup_instructions: Carefully retrieve all 4 cups. Set up an observation station with the science journal, ruler, and magnifying glass. Do NOT discard any samples until all observations are recorded.

slides.text: It has been one week since we started our mummification experiment! Let us check our apple 'mummies.' Remember our cups: 1) Control (nothing), 2) Salt only, 3) Baking soda only, 4) Salt + Baking soda (Natron).

For each apple piece, observe and record: Color — has it changed? How? Size — has it shrunk? Measure it! Texture — is it soft, hard, wrinkled, firm? Smell — does it smell fresh, rotten, or neutral? Use the magnifying glass for details.

Compare your results to your predictions. Which method preserved the apple best? The salt + baking soda mix (like Egyptian natron) should work best because it draws moisture out. The control piece should be the most decayed.

slides.prompt: Record all observations in a data table in your science journal: columns for each cup, rows for color, size, texture, smell, and 'preservation rating' (1-10). Draw or photograph each sample. Write a conclusion: Which method worked best? Why? How does this explain Egyptian mummification?

slides.text: The Egyptians figured out thousands of years ago that salt draws out moisture and prevents decay. This is the same science behind beef jerky, pickles, and preserved fish! Science connects ancient wisdom to modern life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child record accurate observations, rank the preservation methods, and explain why the natron mixture works?

parent_notes: This is the payoff for the Week 10 experiment — children are always excited to see the results. The control apple should be significantly more decayed than the treated ones, and the salt+baking soda mix should be best preserved. If results are unclear, extend the experiment another week. This is real scientific practice: hypothesis, experiment, observation, conclusion. Take photos for the portfolio!

title: Read Aloud — Continued Egypt Reading and Narration
description: Continue the Egypt read-aloud, focusing on daily life, trade, and Egypt's interactions with neighboring civilizations. Practice narration and make connections to geography studies.
instructions:
1. Review the previous chapter.
2. Read the next chapter about Egyptian daily life, trade, or neighbors.
3. Pause for discussion and geographic connections.
4. The child narrates the chapter back.
5. Write a journal entry connecting the reading to other Q2 studies.
6. Preview next week's reading about Ancient India.

slides.heading: Egypt Continued
slides.subheading: Read Aloud — Trade and Daily Life

slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark the next chapter. Have the map ready to trace trade routes. Sit comfortably for reading together.

slides.text: Quick review: What have we learned about Egypt so far? The Nile, pharaohs, pyramids, mummies, hieroglyphics, the Rosetta Stone. Today we continue our journey!

Read the chapter aloud. This might cover Egyptian trade (they traded with Nubia, Punt, and Mediterranean peoples), daily life (we studied this in culture), or Egypt's decline. Pause to show trade routes on the map.
After reading, narrate: tell back the chapter in your own words. Focus on the MOST IMPORTANT information. What was the main idea? What details supported it?

slides.prompt: Write a reading journal entry that connects today's reading to something else we have studied. For example: How does Egyptian trade connect to their geography? How does their social structure connect to the building of pyramids? Write at least one paragraph showing the connection.

slides.text: Egypt's story is winding down in our read-aloud, but its influence lives on. Next week, we travel east to Ancient India — another river civilization with its own incredible story!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child narrate the chapter and make at least one meaningful connection between the reading and another subject?

parent_notes: The connection-making activity is a sophisticated thinking skill. Help the child see links: geography shaped Egypt's isolation (desert barriers), the social pyramid explains who built the monuments (farmers during flood season), trade brought new ideas. These cross-subject connections are the heart of Montessori cosmic education. If the child struggles to make connections, model one and then ask them to find another.
